I work in a tshirt print shop and we use Zinc Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate for discharge printing with water-based screen print ink. We mix it into a clear ink that when printed on a shirt is invisible. When dried down our dryer or with a lighter flame it bleaches out the dyed color of the shirt so we can print light colors on dark shirts.. But also once its dried we can use a uv blacklight to see where that layer is to know if we need to align it more.

Neat little fact, Strontium Aluminate can be found in glow in the dark 3D Printer filament and is quite abrasive, needing a hardened steel or ruby nozzle to be extruded. This is because typical brass nozzles are too soft and get worn away quickly from continuous extrusion of filament with the hard strontium aluminate powder infused within.

I would probably, just to make sure i get as pure zinc sulfate as possible, instead start out by doing a electrolyzing bath of sodium bicarbonate with cheap zinc anodes from a hardware store. This can produce very pure zinc oxide and then you treat that zinc oxide with sulfuric acid to produce the zinc sulfate. This route should produce higher grade zinc sulfate than the one you bought.
Another route to produce Zinc Sulfide is by chemical precipitation using sodium sulfide and zinc acetate dehydrate. This route produce Zinc Sulfide nanoparticles in the solution which have even more uses like in the production of semiconductors. Hope you revisit the topic of this video and see what can be done better and maybe compare routes.

Haven't told this story in a long time, if ever.  My dad was a chemical engineer.  Gawd knows what he was keeping in the basement. But, we were flying paper airplanes into the dusk of a late spring or early summer night.  Just as the sun was slipping away with only a sliver of light, my Dad had came up with a concoction to soak the paper airplanes.  I couldn't have been better timed.  Just as the last few rays of the Sun were giving way to the child's delight of a cool evening in which you could run around to your heart's delight.  And, paper airplanes stained with glowing green were launched into the night.... by a bunch of kids who really needed to burn off some energy... one of which who was me... once upon a time.

Oh God lmfao what you were making is not the stuff they use in glow in the dark toys, what you just made from copying the dude's YouTube video is specifically to make display panels, such as vacuum fluorescent displays(VFDs) and CRT monitors. The guy in the YouTube video who made "doped zinc sulfide" also mentions he is going to make a VFD display panel. Phosphor is what causes the glow in the dark when hit by ultra violet, you could've just bought Phosphor and call it a day. There are many kinds of Phosphor that "luminescence", the type of "luminescence" you want for glow in the dark toys does not requires Zinc Sulfide. Zinc Sulfide doped with copper is used in applications specifically to cause luminescence due to an electromagnetic field or electrons crashing into the doped Zinc Sulfide. What you just made is specfically called "electroluminescence" and it is very inefficient for using as a "glow in the dark". "Electroluminescence" requires high voltage AC electricity to cause the doped Zinc Sulfide to "luminescence", it can however also glow with ultraviolet light but will glow very dimly and is designed not to glow too long, about few seconds it will glow and them stop glowing. "Glow in the dark" stuff which everyone is talking about is called "phosphorescence". "Phosphorescence" is very efficient to "glow in the dark" and is used for applying to toy's surfaces to cause the "luminescence" effect when ultraviolet light hits it and can glow as long as 24 hours. So this video is really a big misunderstanding of what exactly "glow in the dark" chemical really is, and 3+ million people are now going to make "Electroluminescence" for making toys glow in the dark when they could've just bought a much simpler and cheaper proper chemical of "Phosphorescence". The worlds most strongest and brightest "Phosphorescence" is "Strontium Aluminate", Nile should've tried making "Strontium Aluminate" instead of Zinc Sulfide doped with copper lmao. But I gotta say thanks to Nile because I couldn't understand jack nothing what the guy in the youtube was saying and Nile's tutorial was much better to understood and yes, I am making electroluminescence display panels.

Nile, for the last stage of heating it up: I would use a shielding gas. You might want to try using a small 1 litre argon bottle ($20 or $25), used by welders. You will also need a gas valve and piece of silicon hose. Put them together, open the valve enough so that you can feel the gas gently blowing onto your hand. Stick the hose in the test tube, run it for like 20 or 30 seconds to displace all the air out the test tube and you are ready to go with the torch as long as you want. Hope it helps.

It works a lot better milling 2 powders together with a rock tumbler and ceramic balls. Way easier than a mortar and pestle. This is also how I make/mix my black powder. Just throw the powders you wanna mix into the tumbler with about 3/4 filled with ceramic balls and let it run for approx 4 hours.

Add sodium sulfide solution to a stoichemetric amount of zinc nitrate solution.  ZnS precipitates.  Wash several times with distilled water to remove sodium nitrate, filter, resuspend in DH2O, then add trace copper nitrate and/or silver nitrate solution.  Boil dry, then calcine the solids at > 1000c in a kiln for several hours in a covered porcelain or fireclay crucible.  Voila!  Doped ZnS.  For red glow powder, substitute strontium nitrate for zinc nitrate.  Copper doping results in a lime green fluorescence and phosphorescence.  Copper activated/Silver quenched ZnS results in a bright blue fluorescence with no phosphorescence.  I think the Cu/Ag variety requires shortwave UV irradiation, but I don't remember.

A little tip for making suspensions (like the one with epoxy)
1. put the powder in the mortar
2. add aprox. the same amount of liquid and mix it, till its homogenous
3. scratch the sides down so everything is in the middle of the mortar
4. repeat 2+3 until all liquid is added

Thats the way we do in pharmacy and it works 100% with no agglomerats:)

I've tried solvent extraction of the fluorescent agent from Pasante Glow. 50 Pasante Glows were removed from their protective wrappers and placed in a 1L borosilicate beaker. Enough DCM (general reagent grade, Acros) was added to cover the Pasanate Glows. The mixture was then stirred until the polymer dissolved. The resultant solution of polymer dissolved in DCM was found to exhibit fluorescent qualities (evident in a dark room) after it was exposed to light (direct sunlight or a strong flashlight). The resulting solution was transferred to a glass-stoppered conical flask, as I have to explore a means of separating the fluorescent agent from the polymer dissolved in DCM. Once I have worked out a means of isolating the fluorescent agent from the polymer-DCM I'll update and publish the report on SciMad. Considering that the fluorescent agent did not precipitate out from the dissolved polymer in DCM, I doubt that its identity is ZnS, which is insoluble in non-polar organic solvents. Surely, if the fluorescent agent was ZnS,  it would crashed out of the DCM solvent?

is there a video on different metals thermal conductivity? Linus Tech Tips did a video about some Thermal Epoxy that the creator claimed would outperform high end Thermal Grease. Linus did not use it for it's proper use case as he used it for testing if it would work better than 2 types of thermal paste and a graphite pad. Sadly his CPU of choice had a thermal limit of 70 C and he wasn't able to get good results due to inexperience when handling the product (thermal epoxy) and  the thermal limit of the cpu itself. Obviously you would never use thermal epoxy for this use but Linus likes to test things in a normal person manner to see if jank stuff works or not. The CPU used was an older cheap AMD FX CPU which was known for getting hot though with the Thermal Limit of 70 C, I don't see why it had that reputation considering Modern CPUs limit at 100 C before thermal throttling occurs but for obvious reasons, he didn't want to use a modern cpu because first gen Ryzen and newer models are great CPUs and gluing a cooling solution on to one would be wasteful though he did manage to remove the cpu from the cooling solution via hammer and chisel damaging both but leaving them in a working condition.

Brought me back to my BSc years when we would make the ZnS:Cu during solid state chemistry lab exercises - we were using a bit of a simpler method, though - the ZnS by the reaction of ZnSO4 and Na2S2O3, which we would purify via complex forming agents (dimethylglyoxime and diethylthiocarbamate) and activated carbon. Regarding the SrAl2O4:Eu2+ (or Dy3+), this phsophor is way more efficient, since the green photoluminescence can last for hours after excitation. It is e.g. used in emergency exit signs or other related safety phosphors or in toys, as it is non-toxic and high-temperature stable. Besides the reduction step from Eu3+ to Eu2+, it is not really difficult to synthesize. The precursor can be synthesized from the nitrates and urea in a furnace at 600 °C. Due to the reductive atmosphere of the gaseous sideproducts, some of the Eu3+ is already reduced. Afterwards, the precursor can be annealed at higher temperatures (~1000 °C) under Ar/H2 atmosphere in order to reduce the remaining Eu3+ to Eu2+ and to form the final product. A simple tube furnace (which is not very difficult to build) could already reach these temperatures, if the right wires and thermocouples are used.

I'm not sure weather your theory about the purification in Hydrogen Sulfide ist correct. No matter the concentration of metals in your solution, if the reaction probability of all metals with the hydrogen sulfide is about the same, then there would be no purification whatsoever. Statistically speaking the probability of the hydrogen sulfide reacting with the metal ions is only proportional to their concentration, hence no purification.

but if you want to have fun with a bit of solid potassium permanganate, put a bit of it into a ceramic bowland spread it into a thinlayer. It doesn't need to cover the gorund completly but nearly for a good effect.
after that, drip some glycerol (glycerin) ontop of the permanganate.
the permanganate will oxide all three -OH-Groups of the Glycerin as far as possible and this reaction is exothermic enough to set itself aflame. The flame even has a nice purple color.

Wow. I loved your video. It is very nice to see material about luminescence and materials chemistry. Just a quick note. The luminescence of ZnS doped with Cooper ions it is not fosforescence. It is persistent luminescence, which is regular fluorescence but the energy is trapped inside the crystal defects and it's released with the temperature. You can find some references about long lifetime afterglow and ZnS. Also, a cool experiment to see the long lasting luminescence is to hit the UV light after the material is cooled down in Liquid N2.
But I have to say, excellent work. Keep doing fun and interesting experiments like these😊😊

Fun fact about zinc and sulfur: people use that as rocket fuel. This is more popular in countries where safer mixtures are harder to come by, most videos of them aren’t in countries where hobby rocketry is big, like the US, Canada, and Australia. Those are the ones off the top of my head that I know you can fly L3 rockets in. The downside is that it is very static and heat sensitive, and has dangerously high burn rates compared to more safe and powerful propellant formulations. Would make for an interesting video to make some zinc sulfur rocket motors, but if you do, reach out to someone who’s worked with it.

One little suggestion I could give on the final moulding, just from prior experience, is actually not to make it completely opaque but translucent, so that the light will penetrate more of the plastic to activate more of the glow powder, and it will actually glow more intensely because you'll have it coming from inside as well as the surface.

Bottom text

Just wondering, would it have been easier to perform a double displacement reaction? I don't know how readily available these things are but if you had Zinc nitrate and Sodium sulfide those would have reacted together to form the insoluble Zinc Sulfide and the solution could be filtered off. The zinc nitrate probably could have been readily made through addition of the zinc powder to nitric acid but the zinc sulfate also could have been made by adding the zinc to sulfuric acid and the cleanup wouldn't have been necessary. I don't know how available sodium sulfide or a source of soluble sulfide ions would be though but it would probably be easier than working with H2S

2 things:

Did you know that adding a radioactive isotope to your glow powder can make it glow for many years without recharging? This is called radioluminescence, and was once used to make glow-in-the-dark dials for watches. Next step i suggest is to drop in a bunch of radium chloride and make creepy radioactive babies. ☢☢☢

Another interesting property of Cu:ZnS is electroluminescence: this is interesting! Applying a changing electric field to the powder create electrons and holes in the material (M:ZnS is a semiconductor). You will find interesting stuff on youtube, like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUUupR-ongs

Personally, i would be very interested in seeing if Strontium aluminate is electroluminescent (and radioluminescent, but i do not recommend playing with highly radioactive stuff unless you are Cody 😉)

Perhaps this will help you, I make some magnetic samples based on strontium-iron-molybdenum oxides and use a reducing medium in tubural furnace. For this I use activated carbon which reacts with atmospheric oxygen to form carbon monoxide, which already reduces iron and molybdenum oxides to FeO and MoO2. The ends of the tube furnace can be closed with a rubber stopper with thin glass bends and sealed with cotton or silica wool. However, I also use ammonia by passing it under reduced pressure through a tube furnace. For aluminates, this will also work (reducing Eu3+ to Eu2+), but temperatures above 1200 C are already a more difficult task. Good luck and look forward to the video about aluminates)))

New sub here, amazing content. I'm a Ph.D. student in inorganic/materials chem and you're making me miss my lab more than ever, hopefully we'll be back soon. Quick question, do you have a fully operational Schlenk line? I'd recommend using that with Schlenk flasks especially for the H2S step, that stuff's nasty. Parafilm also doesn't provide an airtight seal but at least you were in a fume hood. I work with it regularly, although thankfully I have a cylinder of it. I've also got a badge to wear that beeps if there's ever a leak. Purifying chemicals can be such a huge pain that honestly I don't mind paying more for the extra pure stuff. Also, if you're ever working with metal salts impurities that won't go through typical filter paper (didn't seem to be a problem here), especially Pd salts, use some celite in your glass frit funnel. Saves a lot of time and you don't have to run the filtrate through again usually.
